item.title: Schouw Said to Tap Banks for $2 Billion Fish Feed Unit’s IPO
item.description: Schouw & Co. has picked banks to help arrange a potential Copenhagen initial public offering of Danish industrial fish feed business BioMar Group, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Swetha Gopinath, Pablo Mayo Cerqueiro, Vinicy Chan

media:content.media:description: A bucket of feed at a salmon farm. Photographer: Matthew Lloyd/Bloomberg

item.title: FTSE 100 Live: Pound Rises Ahead of BOE Rate Decision
Zhejiang Sanhua Said to Upsize Hong Kong Listing to $1.2 Billion
item.description: Zhejiang Sanhua Intelligent Controls Co. raised HK$9.3 billion ($1.2 billion) after expanding the size of its Hong Kong share sale and pricing the deal at the top of the marketed range, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Dave Sebastian, Julia Fioretti

media:content.media:description: A gong at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: Stocks Slide as Mideast Escalation Risk Mounts: Markets Wrap
item.description: Equities fell as growing speculation that the US will directly support Israel in its war against Iran fueled geopolitical uncertainty and concerns about the inflationary impact of higher crude prices.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: An electronic ticker displays figures for the Nikkei 225 Stock Average, top, and the Hang Seng Index on a footbridge in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. The US has hit China with the biggest-ever tariff hike on almost all Chinese products, bringing total levies to at least 54%, a move that could decimate Chinese shipments to the world’s largest economy.

item.title: US Officials Plan for Possible Strike on Iran in Coming Days | Bloomberg The Pulse 06/19
item.description:
Senior US officials are preparing for the possibility of a strike on Iran in coming days, according to people familiar with the matter, as Israel and the Islamic Republic continue to exchange fire. Some of them pointed to potential plans for a weekend strike. Top leaders at a handful of federal agencies have begun getting ready for an attack, one person said. A missile from Iran on Thursday struck an Israeli hospital for the first time since the war started almost a week ago, a reminder of the risks to civilians in both countries.
Today's guests: Jari Stehn, Goldman Sachs Chief European Economist, Huw van Steenis, Oliver Wyman Partner and Vice Chair, Greg Fleming, Rockefeller Capital Management President and CEO (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Spain Opposes Rutte’s Plan to Raise NATO Spending Target to 5%
item.description: Spain will oppose NATO plans to raise the target for members’ defense spending to 5%, according to a government official.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

item.title: Thai Stocks Decline to Five-Year Low on Political Upheaval
item.description: Thailand’s equity benchmark index closed at its lowest level since March 2020, after the government’s second-largest party quit the ruling coalition, piling further pressure on Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra.
item.dc:creator: Eduard Gismatullin

item.title: SNB Cuts Rate to Zero and Hints at More to Stop Franc Inflows
item.description: The Swiss National Bank cut its interest rate to zero and signaled it’s ready to go further if necessary as it seeks to deter investors from pushing up the franc.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Martin Schlegel, left, and SNB Board Member Petra Tschudin, at a news conference in Zurich, on June 19. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: Korea’s Cuckoo Set for Malaysia Debut After Scaling Down IPO
item.description: A subsidiary of South Korean home-appliance maker Cuckoo Holdings Co. is set to go public in Malaysia after a scaled-down offering that’s expected to raise 395 million ringgit ($93 million).
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Cuckoo's outlet in Kuala Lumpur. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Indian IPO Market Set for Busy Week With $1.7 Billion in Deals
item.description: India’s primary market is set for its busiest period this year, with at least four companies planning to raise a total of about 150 billion rupees ($1.7 billion) through initial public offerings next week.
item.dc:creator: Rajesh Mascarenhas

media:content.media:description: The National Stock Exchange in Mumbai. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg

item.title: US Economy is Still Resilient, Rockefeller’s Fleming Says
item.description: Despite recent investor caution, the US remains an exceptional economy says Greg Fleming, CEO and President of Rockefeller Capital Management. He sees the economy remaining resilient, and believes that the productivity gains from AI will transform businesses and help the US economy grow its way out of debt and deficits. Fleming spoke to Francine Lacqua on 'Bloomberg: The Pulse'. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Luxury Firms Tackle Slowdown With Cheaper Accessories, Bain Says
item.description: Luxury brands are putting out more affordable and smaller accessories as they seek to generate store traffic to counter slowing demand, a new report shows.
item.dc:creator: Angelina Rascouet

media:content.media:description: A Loewe advertisement in Shanghai, China.

item.title: Goldman’s Stehn on Norges Bank’s Rate Decision
item.description: Goldman Sachs Chief European Economist Jari Stehn discusses the unexpected decision by Norway’s central bank to cut its key deposit rate by a quarter point to 4.25%. “We hadn’t expected that,” Stehn tells Bloomberg’s Francine Lacqua.

item.title: India Rupee at Three-Month Low as Oil Spikes on Mideast Conflict
item.description: The Indian rupee weakened to its lowest level in three months, as a surge in oil prices underscored the nation’s vulnerability to energy shocks.
item.dc:creator: Bhaskar Dutta

media:content.media:description: 500 rupee banknotes counted by a cash counting machine at a currency exchange store in New Delhi, India, on Monday, Feb. 3, 2025. The Indian rupee is expected to weaken further against the dollar, after hitting a new low Monday, as traders bet on interest-rate cuts amid signs the central bank is loosening its grip on the currency under its new chief.

item.title: Oil Swings as Investors Watch for Trump’s Plan on Iran Conflict
item.description: Oil fluctuated as the market remained on alert for whether President Donald Trump will plunge the US into the conflict between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen, Alex Longley

item.title: Good Chance BOE to Speed Up Cuts Later This Year: Stehn
item.description: Goldman Sachs Chief European Economist Jari Stehn discusses what to expect from today’s Bank of England interest rate decision and the outlook for the central bank’s rate-cutting cycle in the coming months. “We think that will then essentially hint towards August,” Stehn says. Speaking on Bloomberg Television, he adds “there’s a good chance” the BOE will “speed up cuts” in the second half of the year.

item.title: Fahmy: Rethinking Strategic Realignment in Region
item.description: Bloomberg sources say senior US officials are preparing for the possibility of a potential strike on Iran in the coming days. Dalia Fahmy, Director of International Relations and Diplomacy and Associate Professor of Political Science at Long Island University told Joumanna Bercetche on Horizons Middle East and Africa that there are questions over the future of international law and warfare, and international norms based in law. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Russia Oil Revenue Dented by Strong Ruble as Global Prices Jump
item.description: Russia is barely benefiting from the recent surge in oil prices because of its strengthening currency, keeping the Kremlin’s revenue under pressure.
item.dc:creator: James Herron

item.title: China’s Top Soy Sauce Maker Rises in Hong Kong Trading Debut
item.description: Foshan Haitian Flavouring & Food Co., China’s biggest soy sauce maker, edged up in its Hong Kong trading debut after its HK$10.1 billion ($1.3 billion) stock offering drew strong demand from investors.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Kelly Li

media:content.media:description: Foshan Haitian soy sauce. Source: CFOTO/Future Publishing/Getty Images

item.title: Shell CEO Warns of ‘Huge Impact’ If Strait of Hormuz Blocked
item.description: Shell Plc, one of the biggest traders of oil and natural gas, has contingency plans in case the conflict between Israel and Iran disrupts flows from the region, warning that a potential blockage of the Strait of Hormuz could deliver a substantial shock.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Shery Ahn

media:content.media:description: An oil tanker. Photographer: Ali Mohammadi/Bloomberg

item.title: India’s Largest Port in the Making to Raise $3.5 Billion Debt
item.description: The firm building what will become the largest port in India plans to raise as much as 300 billion rupees ($3.5 billion) of debt, giving lenders an opportunity to invest in one of the cornerstones of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s infrastructure overhaul.
item.dc:creator: Saikat Das

media:content.media:description: MUMBAI, INDIA - JUNE 20: Unmesh Wagh, IRS, Chairman, of Jawaharlal Nehru Port Authority (JNPA), addressing to media during press conference on "Development of an all weather greenfield deep draft Major Port at Vadhvan, after approval for setting up Port at Vadhvan, given by Cabinet, at Nariman Point on June 20, 2024 in Mumbai, India. (Photo by Anshuman Poyrekar/Hindustan Times via Getty Images)

item.title: Gold and CHF Are Portfolio-Diversifiers: 3-Minute MLIV
item.description: Anna Edwards, Kriti Gupta and Mark Cudmore break down today's key themes for analysts and investors on "Bloomberg: The Opening Trade." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Vietnamese Dong Drops to Record Low as Asian Currencies Weaken
item.description: The Vietnamese dong fell, dropping below a record low it touched in April, as Asian currencies declined following a report the US is preparing for a possible strike on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Karl Lester M Yap, Linh Vu Nguyen

item.title: Gillian Tett on Complex Derivatives and the Fifth Stage of Capitalism
item.description: What is the role of modern finance?
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

item.title: Gillian Tett on Complex Derivatives and the Fifth Stage of Capitalism
item.description: After the GFC, there was a lot of angst over the fact that so much effort and brainpower went into designing complex derivatives, and other financial instruments. Not only was this seen as wasteful, the complexity was deemed to be the heart of the crisis, and therefore bad. But all these years later, looking back, how bad is financial complexity really? What do things look like from the perspective of 2025. On this episode we’re joined by Gillian Tett, a columnist at the Financial Times, and als
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Unique Moment for US to Address "Geopolitical Headache" in Iran: Amundi
item.description:
The odds of US involvement in the Israel-Iran conflict are "quite high," says Anna Rosenberg, Head of Geopolitics at the Amundi Investment Institute. "It's probably going to be a difficult moment for the US to act," she adds, but "acting comes with a lot of consequences too."
(Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Says More Regional Trade Can Offset Global Losses
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said greater trade in the region could help compensate for losses suffered as a result of global fragmentation.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Daryna Krasnolutska

item.title: SNB Introduces Stealth Negative Rate to Keep Money Markets Going
item.description: The Swiss National Bank may have cut its interest rate to zero, but the way it penalizes banks’ excess reserve holdings means lenders will face negative rates if they park too much cash at the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Martin Schlegel, president of the Swiss National Bank (SNB), during the bank's rate announcement news conference in Zurich, Switzerland, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. The Swiss National Bank cut its interest rate to zero, seeking to deter investors from pushing up the franc after the currency’s strength caused consumer prices to drop for the first time in four years. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa Declares National Disaster After Floods Kill 92
item.description: South Africa declared a national disaster after floods and snow killed more than 90 people and destroyed roads and bridges in four of the country’s nine provinces.
item.dc:creator: Rene Vollgraaff

media:content.media:description: A resident of an informal settlement stands on his porch in front of his belongings after a flood near Mthatha on June 12/

item.title: CVC Capital Seeks $400 Million Loan for BAPE Dividend Payout
item.description: CVC Capital Partners Plc is in talks with banks for a $400 million loan to fund a payout to the shareholders of a clothing company, A Bathing Ape, which it co-owns, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Kari Soo Lindberg

media:content.media:description: A BAPE store in Tokyo. Photographer: Jun Sato/WireImage/Getty Images
